intro: Paris polyphylla subsp. marmorata, commonly known as the marbled ginger, is a perennial herb native to the eastern Himalayas. It belongs to the family Zingiberaceae and is characterized by its striking, marbled-patterned leaves. The plant produces clusters of fragrant, pale yellow to white flowers during the summer months. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forested areas at elevations between 1,500 and 3,000 meters. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is sometimes cultivated for horticultural purposes.
